titleStmt.title: George Wastnes Esquire, in com∣mendation of the Author.

publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

analytic.title: George Wastnes Esquire, in com∣mendation of the Author.

monogr.title: Philotimus. The warre betwixt nature and fortune. Compiled by Brian Melbancke student in Graies Inne
monogr.author: Melbancke, Brian

div.head: George Wastnes Esquire, in commendation of the Author.

lg.l: FAine would I prayse my dearest swetest frend,
Yet do I feare my praise will worke disgrace,
How shuold I praise where none can ought amend,
Nor any Momus this his worke deface?
If Fortune would agree with natures gyftes,
If God and Fortune once would deigne to smile,
A mirrour of a man, were Melbancke than,
Whose wit, whose art, whose vertues, now surpasse.
In these his youthfull yeares to haue such skill?
And now to vertues lore to frame his will?
What learned age with ours once dare compare,
Since Melbancke liues, whose learning is so rare?
God prosper thee (my sugred darling boy)
God gyue thee once thy hearts desired ioy,
And if I liue, my loue shall proue no toy,
But thou shalt find that Wastnes is thine owne. Adue.

closer.signed: Thine as his owne, G. VVastnes. Erras, virtus fortunae famula.
